hero_image.alt: Outside view of the Luzhniki Stadium
hero_image.description: Outside view of the Luzhniki Stadium

paragraphs: Luzhniki Stadium is a sports stadium in Moscow, Russia. Its total seating capacity is 81,000 seats, all covered (upgraded). The stadium is a part of the Luzhniki Olympic Complex, and is located in Khamovniki District of the Central Administrative Okrug of Moscow city.
The name Luzhniki derives from the flood meadows in the bend of Moskva River where the stadium was built, translating roughly as 'The Meadows'. Its the biggest stadium in eastern Europe.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Opening ceremony of the 1980 Olympic Games
hero_image.description: Opening ceremony of the 1980 Olympic Games

paragraphs: The stadium was built in 1955–56 as the Grand Arena of the Central Lenin Stadium.
The stadium was officially opened on 31 July 1956, having been built in just 450 days. It was the national stadium of the Soviet Union, and is now the national stadium of Russia.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Interior view of the Luzhniki Stadium
hero_image.description: Interior view of the Luzhniki Stadium

paragraphs: The original stadium was demolished in 2013 to give a way for the construction of a new stadium.
The self-supported cover was retained. The facade wall was retained as well, due to its architectural value and later was reconnected to a new building.

he Luzhniki Stadium has been selected by the Russia 2018 FIFA World Cup bid as the venue for the final, which will be held on 15 July 2018. The stadium will then join Rome's Stadio Olimpico, Berlin's Olympiastadion, Munich's Olympiastadion, Saint Denis' Stade de France and London's old Wembley Stadium as the only stadiums to have hosted the finals of the FIFA World Cup, UEFA's European Cup/Champions League and featured as a main stadium of the Summer Olympic Games.

intro_text: The stadium is divided into four sectors each of which is broken down into smaller blocks. Each block is connected to a corridor by a single exit, which means visitors won’t get lost searching for their seat in the wrong block.
The blocks are numbered in large numbers both from the side of the corridors and the arena. Large numbers facing the arena help personnel quickly locate the right place.

images.alt: Luzhniki Stadium more detailed seating plan
images.description: Luzhniki Stadium more detailed seating plan

images.description: Entrance turning gates of the Luzhiniki Stadium

hero_image.alt: Panorama exterior view of the Spartak Stadium.
hero_image.description: Panorama exterior view of the Spartak Stadium.

paragraphs: Spartak Stadium (Otkrytiye Arena) is a multi-purpose stadium in Moscow, Russia.
The venue is used mostly for football matches, hosting the home matches of Spartak Moscow and occasionally the Russian national team.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: A sculpture of the Roman Gladiator Spartacus, for whom the club is named, in the square outside the stadium
hero_image.description: A sculpture of the Roman Gladiator Spartacus, for whom the club is named, in the square outside the stadium

paragraphs: The groundbreaking ceremony was held on 2 July 2007, but construction was delayed multiple times for different reasons.
Construction was scheduled to be completed between 2009 and 2010 but, as of 2009, the stadium was still in the design stage.
The stadium officially opened on 5 September 2014.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Otkrytiye Arena inside
hero_image.description: Otkrytiye Arena inside

paragraphs: Spartak Stadium was one of four stadiums used for the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup.
During the FIFA World Cup 2018, 5 matches will be played at this stadium (4 Group Matches and 1 Round of 16 Match).

images.alt: Transportation schemes for the Spartak Stadium
images.description: Transportation schemes for the Spartak Stadium

hero_image.alt: An exteriour view of the new soccer stadium on Krestovsky Island which will host some 2018 World Cup matches in St. Petersburg, Russia.
hero_image.description: An exteriour view of the new soccer stadium on Krestovsky Island which will host some 2018 World Cup matches in St. Petersburg, Russia.

paragraphs: The Krestovsky Stadium, officially Saint-Petersburg Stadium, also called Zenit Arena, is a retractable roof stadium in the western portion of Krestovsky Island in Saint Petersburg, Russia, which serves as home for FC Zenit Saint Petersburg.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: The later stages of stadium construction.
hero_image.description: The later stages of stadium construction.

paragraphs: The stadium has been built on the location where the former Kirov Stadium used to stand before it was demolished.
The stadium was opened in 2017 for the FIFA Confederations Cup.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: The later stages of stadium construction.
hero_image.description: The later stages of stadium construction.

paragraphs: The stadium will host 7 matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup including the semi-final and the third-place-playoff.

images.alt: Map of how to get to Krestovskiy stadium from Sportivnaya Metro Station
images.description: Map of how to get to Krestovskiy stadium from Sportivnaya Metro Station

images.alt: An ariel view of the new soccer stadium on Krestovsky Island.
images.description: An ariel view of the new soccer stadium on Krestovsky Island.

hero_image.alt: Fisht stadium and the sea view.
hero_image.description: Fisht stadium and the sea view.

paragraphs: Fisht Olympic Stadium is an outdoor stadium in Sochi, Russia. Located in Sochi Olympic Park and named after Mount Fisht, the 40,000-capacity stadium was constructed for the 2014 Winter Olympics and Paralympics, where it served as the venue for their opening and closing ceremonies.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Olympic stadium 'Fisht' in Sochi. It is constructed for the XXII Winter Olympic games in Sochi in 2014.
hero_image.description: Olympic stadium 'Fisht' in Sochi. It is constructed for the XXII Winter Olympic games in Sochi in 2014.

paragraphs: In January 2015, a project began to renovate the stadium in preparation for the FIFA Confederations Cup and World Cup; among other changes, the closed roof was removed in order to make the stadium compliant with FIFA regulations.
The work was expected to be completed by June 2016, but the completion date was pushed back to November 2016.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Fisht Olympic Stadium during a 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup match in June 2017.
hero_image.description: Fisht Olympic Stadium during a 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup match in June 2017.

paragraphs: The stadium was originally built as an enclosed facility; it was re-opened in 2016 as an open-air football stadium, to host matches as part of the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup and 2018 FIFA World Cup.
The stadium will host 6 matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup, 4 Group Matches, 1 Round-of-16 Match and 1 Quarter Final Match.

hero_image.alt: Ariel view of the Nizhny Novgorod Stadium.
hero_image.description: Ariel view of the Nizhny Novgorod Stadium.

paragraphs: Nizhny Novgorod Stadium is a football stadium in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia.
It is one of the venues for the 2018 FIFA World Cup. It will have a capacity of 44,899 spectators.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Ariel view of Nizhny Novgorod Stadium with the Volga river in the background.
hero_image.description: Ariel view of Nizhny Novgorod Stadium with the Volga river in the background.

paragraphs: At the end of 2014, the Ministry of Sport of the Russian Federation signed a contract for the construction of the stadium.
Works on the construction of the stadium 'Nizhny Novgorod' began in 2015.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: 3D model of the stadium interior.
hero_image.description: 3D model of the stadium interior.

paragraphs: The capacity of the stadium will be 45,000 seats, including 902 seats for low-mobility groups of people together with accompanying persons.
The stadium will host 6 matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup, 4 Group Matches, 1 Round-of-16 Match and 1 Quarter Final Match.

images.alt: Map of how to get to Nizhny Novgorod Stadium from the metro statition or train station.
images.description: Map of how to get to Nizhny Novgorod Stadium from the metro statition or train station.

hero_image.description: Ariel view of the kaliningrad stadium territory.

paragraphs: Kaliningrad Stadium (also called Arena Baltika) is an association football stadium located in Oktyabrsky Island, Kaliningrad, Russia.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Construction site of FIFA World Cup 2018 stadium in Kaliningrad.
hero_image.description: Construction site of FIFA World Cup 2018 stadium in Kaliningrad.

paragraphs: Preparation work for construction of the infrastructure started in January 2015.
The project is based on the concept of the Allianz Arena, which hosted matches of the 2006 World Cup in Germany.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Exterior view of the facade of the Kaliningrad Stadium.
hero_image.description: Exterior view of the facade of the Kaliningrad Stadium.

paragraphs: The stadium will host 4 group stage matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup.

hero_image.alt: Ekaterinburg stadium at dusk.
hero_image.description: Ekaterinburg stadium at dusk.

paragraphs: Ekaterinburg Arena (Central Stadium) is a multi-purpose stadium in Yekaterinburg, Russia.The capacity of the stadium is just over 35,000.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: 10 world diplomats visit Ekaterinburg Stadium.
hero_image.description: 10 world diplomats visit Ekaterinburg Stadium.

paragraphs: Central Stadium was built in 1957. The Stadium has hosted thousands of sports and entertainment events.
From September 2006 to 2011, it completed a first large-scale stadium reconstruction. In 2015-17 completed another large-scale reconstruction.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Ekaterinburg Arena 3D model.
hero_image.description: Ekaterinburg Arena 3D model.

paragraphs: As the stadium was chosen as one of the venues of the 2018 FIFA World Cup, temporary stands extending outside the original perimeter of the stadium were erected so as to comply with the FIFA requirement of seatings for 35,000 spectators.
The stadium will host 4 group stage matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup.

hero_image.description: General view outside the stadium prior to the FIFA Confederations Cup Russia 2017 Semi-Final Match.

paragraphs: Kazan Arena is a stadium in Kazan, Russia.The stadium has the largest outside screen in Europe.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Kazan Arena football stadium
hero_image.description: Kazan Arena football stadium

paragraphs: The stadium's construction started in May 2010 and was completed in July 2013.
The stadium hosted the 2013 Summer Universiade opening and closing ceremonies, and some matches of the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Kazan Arena stadium before a match.
hero_image.description: Kazan Arena stadium before a match.

paragraphs: The stadium will host 6 matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup tournament (4 Group Stage matches, 1 Round of 16 match and 1 Quarter final match).

hero_image.description: 3D Model of Mordovia Arena

paragraphs: Mordovia Arena is a football stadium located in Saransk, Mordovia, Russia in time for the 2018 FIFA World Cup.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Final stages of Mordovia Arena stadium construction.
hero_image.description: Final stages of Mordovia Arena stadium construction.

paragraphs: The stadium constructin broke ground in 2010. The simple bowl-shaped venue is to have stands for 44,442 people, but only in tournament mode.
After the 2018 World Cup upper stands are to be dismantled, decreasing capacity to 28,000.
Between the stands left and the roof a promenade with retail and leisure spaces is to be created.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.description: 3D model of Mordovia Arena at night.

paragraphs: The stadium will host 4 group stage matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup.

hero_image.alt: Exterior view of Rostov Arena stadium's facade.
hero_image.description: Exterior view of Rostov Arena stadium's facade.

paragraphs: Rostov Arena is an association football stadium located in Rostov-on-Don, Russia.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Ariel view of Rostov Arena stadium during the final stages of construction.
hero_image.description: Ariel view of Rostov Arena stadium during the final stages of construction.

paragraphs: In June 2013, during the groundbreaking for the stadium, five shells from WWII were found, almost perfectly preserved.
In August 2013, work began on the sandy alluvium foundation for the stadium. Work on the foundation was completed in May 2014.
The stadium is to be the start of a new city centre. It will be the first large project built on the southern bank of the Don River, with the rest of the city lying north.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Rostov arena interior and the newly grown grass on the football pitch.
hero_image.description: Rostov arena interior and the newly grown grass on the football pitch.

paragraphs: The stadium will host 5 matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup; 4 Group Matches and 1 Round-of-16 Match.

hero_image.description: 3D Model of Samara Arena at night.

paragraphs: Samara Arena (Cosmos Arena) is a football stadium located in Samara, Russia. The stadium is one of the venues for the 2018 FIFA World Cup.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Samara Arena in its final stages of construction.
hero_image.description: Samara Arena in its final stages of construction.

paragraphs: Samara Arena's design concept is dominated by the theme of space, as a tribute to the traditions of the region, and its renowned aerospace sector.
The history of the city is closely related to rocket and missile engineering.
Samara Rocket Space Center produced 1660 carrier rockets of Soyuz series used for spaceflight launches.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

hero_image.alt: Ariel view of Samara Arena stadium territory.
hero_image.description: Ariel view of Samara Arena stadium territory.

paragraphs: The stadium will host 6 matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup, 4 Group Matches, 1 Round-of-16 Match and 1 Quarter Final Match.

hero_image.description: Ariel view of Volgograd Arena and the sorrounding buildings.

paragraphs: Volgograd Arena is a football stadium located in Volgograd, Russia.

info_sections.title: History

hero_image.alt: Volgograd Arena stadium during the final stages of construction.
hero_image.description: Volgograd Arena stadium during the final stages of construction.

paragraphs: The Stadium will be built on site of the demolished Central Stadium, at the foot of the Mamayev Kurgan memorial complex, near the Volga River.
The previous stadium was built in 1958, on the site of a former oil depot.

info_sections.title: 2018 FIFA World Cup

paragraphs: The stadium will host 4 group stage matches of the 2018 FIFA World Cup.
